page.title: 02Pontycymer-the Garw valley
page.content: The Garw Valley is one of three converging on Bridgend. Situated at the northern end of the valley it is the largest settlement. The narrow valley gives Pontycymer its linear shape. Owing to the high relief, Pontycymer and the valley are socially independent of neighbouring valleys. The river Garw is a tributary of the Ogmore and is locally called the"black river" because of its high content of coal dust, although during the recent miners strike(1984-85) it became resonably clean. The Valley derives its name from the river which is rapid and tempestuous,"Garw" being the Welsh for rough. Pontycymer is based on Carboniferous rocks consisting mainly of Pennant sandstone, and beneath the sandstone the coal seams are found.
